comment: He enjoys listening to himself talk and uses a lot of words to say very little. I was excited for this class, and very disappointed afterwards.

This class is a joke, if you have the opportunity to drop and take a different class for ethnic studies I would. The entire class is based on multiple choice quizzes of obscure questions. No room to show any creativity or ideas. The professor himself is will not give students any leeway or any chance to get their grade up. Just awful.

Dr. Soldatenko is a great professor at Cal Poly. His class is very lecture-heavy, however the lectures are based on slides published on Canvas. The grade is based solely on quizzes and exams, and there is no homework besides reading the text. The quizzes and exams are very fair and are based on the lecture slides.

Very clearly summarizes hw material in class and all test material is gone over in class. Very helpful and loves when students participate. A very cool guy to get to know outside of class. Passionate about Latinx studies (Cal Poly). Multiple choice quizzes and midterm make up your grade. Definitely recommend.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: i think the course could be considered difficult and challenging, especially if you don't apply yourself. but with that being said, i think it'd be harder to fail this class than to pass it. there were weekly discussion posts that are pass or fail. 3-4 question quizzes. 2 short papers and a final 1. deadlines weren't super firm, only on the papers.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: It's supposedly an "intro" class. There's three question quizzes after each lecture, which are over an hour long and sometimes there's multiple lecture videos in a week. If you missed one question, you fail the quiz, which was really crappy. Take it if you're actually wanting to learn about philosophy, otherwise, avoid this class at all costs.

This class is a lot of work and hard.... There are 2 lectures each week (both being over an hour long) then two three question quizzes after (if you get one question wrong your fail). On top of that every other week there is a discussion post with over 500 words and you must reply to two people. On top of that you have the short answer tests on LD.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: He grades the tests really hard and they are all short answer questions. He also did not grade the discussion posts until the day grades were due so you really had no idea what your grade was in the class. I learned a lot but I don't think my grade reflects it. Mostly it was just frustrating because you could never figure out what he wanted.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: His lectures were great. However, he has these 3 question quizzes, that if you missed one question, you would fail the entire thing. He is also a hard grader for his open response exams, which he takes a long time to grade. As I typing this, it has been 4 days after grades were due and I am still waiting on my final exam grade.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: If you're interested in philosophy then I recommend taking this course. However, this class is definitely not an easy A and requires a lot of work. The study guides are the tests, each question has to be a "small essay" and make sure it's exactly what was said in class plus more.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Professor Soldatenko is fantastic. I've taken him twice. He is passionate about what he teaches and I've come away from both classes with a new perspective on the world. He teaches this like a true college class should be taught, no busy work and it's up to you to do well. Great man and great teacher, highly recommend.

The professor is a nice guy and is more than welcome to go back over the content he is discussing if you don't understand. All he does is talk. For his exams he is VERY specific and by that I mean you basically need to write down EXACTLY what he says to get the points. If you take good notes and pay attention you should be good. I never read...
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Online class, did not bother to get back with any personal emails from other students or myself. The only time we heard from this man is when we would all keep harassing him with emails and he had to answer tho whole class. We have only got SOME of are grades back in the last week of school and he grades super hard and had our exam messed up.

This is the hardest class I have taken. You must pat attention and you will not pass if you do not come to class. There are also movie reviews due every test day, in class. You must watch these old philosophical movies and write a 2-3 page paper relating it back to the current topic in class. HARD!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Horrible. Received all grades the last two weeks of the semester. If you want to learn something with a professor who cares about his students, avoid this guy at all costs. He focuses on equality and opportunity regardless of race or gender, he's got it covered- everyone equally gets no feedback or support. Worst professor.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Lecture based class, but nevertheless, the man is very passionate about what he teaches. I would recommend to take.

The worst class I have ever taken. Zero feedback- he doesn't follow through by grading the assignments. Does not respond to email. Tough grader with no explanation until after you finally receive the grade- by then it's too late! Just don't.

He said it was challenging but that was the hardest thing I've ever done in my life. 4.0 student and I ended with a C. If you don't write down exactly what he says for the test you're done. Great guy, not so great professor.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He is an amazing lecturer, and really interested in the material. He is willing to work with you - I was out of class for 4 weeks, and he allowed me to make up exams, and work with me in order to learn the material. You must show up to class, but don't worry, it is not a boring class! He makes learning philosophy fun. You have to work for yourgrade

Great professor , passionate and know Ls material. Class is good just do not take if other classes are tough that semester. Readings are very time consuming and tough to grasps. Test are 10 essay / short answers questions that require tons of detail
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Get ready to read--Respected

comment: He has long lectures, and if you want to pass the test you need all of the notes. Gives a study guide for the test, but his tests are a bunch of essay type questions. In order to get an A you need to know every detail from the notes, and it takes a lot of studying to do well in this class.

He lectures every single class. Gives you just about everything you need to know. Tests are straight from lectures. Tests are also all short answer. A lot of work. I would not take this class again. Its talk about a lot of old people no one cares about. He also takes a year and a day to grade papers and exams.

If you count how many times he says "right" during class, you'll be amazed. That and it makes you *listen* to the long lectures! (Highest count to date is 417 "right" repetitions in a 75min class, only counting those that were extraneous, right.)

I really enjoyed this class and am now considering changing my minor to philosophy because of it. His lectures are long but interesting and there is a good bit of reading but nothing crazy. The exams are 10 very long answer questions. Be prepared to spend the entire test time brain dumping everything you know about the question. I loved the class.

Lectures all class long, interesting and wants you to understand but any interest is ruined by exams! Tests are all essay and if you do not write half a page and have every detail, he will count off! Do not take this professor if you are not a philosophy major!  His grading is not concise and he is over critical!!!

Tough class but he knows his stuff.  Always gives really good feedback and lets you know where you missed points.  Sometimes the material is a little dry but for the most part it's not too bad.  No textbook which is nice, just download the readings he puts online.

Great professor. Extremely helpful, always lets us ask questions. Reading is assigned but it's not necessary. Test questions are directly from the study guide. If you take good notes and remember them, you'll make an A.

Gives detailed study guides and is extremely helpful in answering any questions. The type of teacher that is passionate in what he teachers and confidant in what he knows. Exams are dense and difficult but so is the material. Gives plenty of opportunities for extra credit through attending lectures of guest speakers. Go to class if you want to pass

Professor Soldatenko is a nice and cool guy, but the class is difficult. The subject matter is interesting but he grades really tough on the tests. You have to put a lot of detail into your answers and that is usually a lot of information you have to retain.

Dr. Soldatenko is, hands down, the best professor I have ever had in the five years I have been at KSU. Yes, his classes are a challenge but the key to doing well is 1. Don't miss class 2. Pay close attention and 3.TAKE NOTES! It's as simple as that.

The course content is interesting and the assignments are okay. Sometimes it feels like busy work but alright. The prof is a little off his rocker and does NOT grade fairly. He bases the grades or assignments on other ppls papers. matter what you do or how much effort you put into your work, he always grades super harshly. Cool class prof no.

In this class you can NOT  miss a day. If you do, you will be lost. & good luck w/ having classmates who will help fill you in on a day you missed. Even when you feel like you explained a lot you will still get a 2 out of 5.

He's a very nice guy...but thats about it. IF If you're not a philosophy major...AVOID!!! He grades extremely hard and on tests it seemed like he was just looking for reasons to count off points. I enjoyed the subject matter to an extent but he definitely ruined the experience for me. Hated going, hated failing (even though i studied my bum off).

prof is a good guy with good intentions in the class. however he always says you can "expound upon what you gave me". three people out of 20 passed this class (me included) after about 6 had dropped. if you already get philosophy should be fine but avoid this class if you dont. i thought it was going to be fun, but i ended up dreading going.

Excellent professor, he works with you if you work with him. He appreciates those who do the readings & who visit his office hours. The class material can be quite confusing at times, but he does his best to make it clear. Definitely highly recommend taking him. WARNING: His tests are difficult. He calls them short answer, but is expecting more like a paragraph per question and it is recommended you throw everything you know about that subject into the answer to get full credit.

Great teacher, my favorite so far, really explicit and if you pay close attention everything he says will be on the test, this class requires a lot of heavy reading but other tan that, my favorite class so far

Best professor so far. Very open-minded, intelligent, and wants the students' feedback. There was a lot of reading, but he never made us read anything boring or useless. Exams from the study-guide. Willing to explain everything as many times as you need it. Favorite course and favorite professor this semester! Definitely recommend!

Wonderful class!Gives very detailed notes.His exam questions are pulled directly from the study guide.Incredibly dense material,but life-changing!This has to be one of my fav classes and professors at KSU.Three movie reviews, 3 exams, Final, and extra credit opportunities. There's no reason not to get an A!Very nice & personable man!LOVE THIS CLASS

Great professor, very friendly, and makes sometimes dense material clear. Spoon feeds you detailed notes, and distributes a list of 10 or so study questions that are identical to what he puts on the essay exams. No excuse for poor performance, then. As per any philosophy course, though, there is a LOT of reading. Fascinating course.

would not recommend this class unless you already love Philosophy. There is A LOT of dense reading that's confusing. The 4 tests are essay questions, he grades against other students answers. Half the kids in my class dropped out after the first test and half the remaining students weren't passing. If you need to maintain your GPA steer clear:(

Warm and amiable, he'll patiently explain difficult (sometimes tedious) readings. Ran class like a graduate-level course, which consisted in student-led discussions and presentations. Informal and conversational. One of the best professors I've ever had.

First of all, Dr. Soldatenko was  a great professor; I've never enjoyed a class quite as much, even as a philosophy major. His class does require a lot of reading, a fair amount of abstract thought, and decent note-taking skills.  He teaches class as it should be taught. This is a college course, not a high school level course.
Not easy, pretty unclear about what he expects, format changed every test. Grades in comparison to other students. Way too much material and reading. DO NOT RECOMMEND.

Alot of reading but you dont really have to read anything bc every thing you need to know is give in class. TAKE GOOD NOTES if you do then this class will be easy to pass alot of people will make a B in the class. very nice professor and will give as much help as you want. test are all short answer and there is extra credit. 500 word essay.

Don't take this class unless you are a humanities major. I am an accounting major and took this class as an elective because it looked interesting and is a 2000 level class. I found the readings very hard to follow, and the entire focus of the class to be very unclear. Proff Soldatenko is a nice guy, but I wish someone warned me about this class.
